Detroit, MI, 48205-2748
Re: License #: CB820315857
SI #: 2025SIC0000845
Dear Mr. Britt:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
*WARNING: THIS REPORT CONTAINS QUOTED PROFANITY*
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000845
Special Investigation Intake Date: July 8, 2025
License #: CB820315857
Licensee Group Organization: Community Care Organization
Licensee Designee: Kendra Washington
Chief Administrator: Darnell Britt
Agency Name: COMMUNITY CARE ORGANIZATION
Agency Address: 18688 Joann Street
Detroit, MI 48205-2748
License Status: 1st Provisional
License Expiration Date: 02/17/2026
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
7/9/2025 10:00 AM Phone Interview
7/9/2025 10:24 AM Phone Special Investigation Initiation
7/9/2025 10:30 AM Phone Special Investigation Initiation
7/9/2025 10:36 AM Phone Special Evaluation
7/9/2025 11:00 AM Face to Face Interview
7/9/2025 2:30 PM Face to Face Interview
8/4/2025 2:00 PM Phone Interview
1

8/4/2025 3:15 PM MDHHS MDHHS -Disposition – No findings
Disposition
8/4/2025 4:30 PM Phone Interview
8/7/2025 10:00 AM Phone Interview
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Description • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A stayed at a friend's home for a couple of days. When
Youth A returned, she found that staff had packed her belongings.
Staff have been threatening to kick Youth A out of the home even
though staff are responsible for her. Staff keep telling Youth A to
abort the baby, has called her, a “dumbass” for getting pregnant,
and tells Youth A she is stupid and going to end up alone on the
streets. When Youth A asks staff for help, staff either do not
respond at all, hang up on Youth A, or asks Youth A, "What the F
do you want me to do about it?"
Another allegation alleges male staff members are having
inappropriate sexual relationships with the female youth in the
program.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 7/9/2025 via telephone. She
reported the same information as the allegations and identified
Program Manager as the person who threatened to kick her out of
the program, call her inappropriate names and told her to abort
her child. Youth A reported she is currently living with her
boyfriend but did not want to give the address. When questioned
about the staff who she asked for help, call her stupid, and a
“dumbass” and told her "What the F do you want me to do about
it?" Youth A reported all of these statements came from Program
Manager.
Regarding the inappropriate male staff having inappropriate
sexual relationships with the female youth was addressed. Youth
A reported one of her former peers who was in the program told
her she walked in on a youth and a male staff having sex. She
2

reported she did not believe in this youth because this youth often
lie. Youth A reported she did not witness these interactions
between a male staff and/or a youth while she was in the program.
Youth A identified Youth D, who shared this information with her
but did not have a male staff name or when/date this incident
occurred.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed on 7/9/2025, face to
face with MDHHS Worker. Program Manager denied the
allegations. PM reported she attempted to assist Youth A while
she was in the program, but Youth A did not want any help or
assistance from the program. She reported that Youth A is often
AWOL and does not report to the program. She reported she did
inform Youth A she was going to request her removal from the
program because she was not following any program
requirements. PM denied calling Youth A inappropriate names
and stated she does not curse at any of the youths in the program.
PM reported Youth A began to AWOL off and on in March, 2025
and beginning of April 2025, she started completing therapy with
her biological father and started discussing issues of sexual
abuse. PM reported Youth A’s behaviors escalated rapidly
(consistent AWOL’s, not attending school) after Youth A testified
in court against her biological mother.
PM reported no one was stealing Youth A’s belongings and Youth
A’s belongings were dropped off at DHHS on 7/7/2025 due to
being AWOL for nine days. She reported after being absent from
the program over five days, the program does not hold placement.
PM reported someone else was waiting for placement and since
Youth A had no contact with the agency and was absent for nine
days, placement was no longer available for her. PM expressed
her interest in really wanting to help Youth A.
PM denied knowledge of any staff having inappropriate sexual
relationships with any of the youths. She reported she currently
has three male staff members who works for the agency. She
provided the male staff contact information for interviews.
Case Manager 1 was interviewed on 7/9/2025, via face to face.
She reported she has been employed for the agency for one
month. Case Manager 1 reported she works in the program daily
and she has never met Youth A. She reported she had recently
taken Youth A’s clothing and personal items to the DHHS office in
Inkster. Case Manager 1 reported she has never observed PM
swearing and berating any of the youths. She reported in her
opinion the PM has a big heart, and she goes above and beyond
3

for the youths in the program.
Case Manager 1 denied knowing anything about inappropriate
sexual relationships between male staff and the female youths in
the program.
Case Manager 2 was interviewed on 7/9/2025, via face to face.
She reported she has worked for the program since 2020 and
works in all the program houses. She reported she has never
seen or heard PM swear or be inappropriate to the youths in the
programs. Case Manager 2 reported she knew Youth A well. She
reported Youth A was close to another youth in the program and
when that youth left early this year, Youth A started spending
much of her time with her boyfriend around March, 2025. Case
Manager 2 reported Youth A’s attitude changed, and she started
going AWOL and missing curfews. Case Manager 2 explained
that if a curfew is missed, the youths need a police escort to enter
back into their home placement. Case Manager 2 reported staff
attempted on several occasions to call and reach out to Youth A
and follow up with her when she was AWOL or was late returning
to the program, but Youth A would not answer her telephone.
Case Manager 2 denied knowing anything about inappropriate
sexual relationship between male staff and the female youths in
the program. Case Manager 2 works the afternoon shift and does
not work on the midnight shift with the male staff. She reported
having no concerns or hearing any inappropriate sexual
conversations/gossip between the male staff and youths in the
program.
Independent Living Specialist 1 was interviewed on 8/2/2025,
via telephone. He has worked for the agency since January of
2025. He reported he works the midnight shift and rarely comes
into contact with the youths in the program. He reported he has no
knowledge of any male staff having any type of inappropriate
sexual relationship with one of the youths in the program. He
reported he has not heard anyone gossiping about this issue
between staff and youth. He denied ever being sexually involved
with a female youth in the program.
Independent Living Specialist 2 was interviewed on 8/2/2025,
via telephone. He reported he has worked for the agency for a
year and 8 months. He works the midnight shift and denied having
knowledge or hearing any type of communication regarding
sexually inappropriate relationship between a youth and a male
staff. He denied ever being sexually involved with a female youth
4

in the program. He offered no additional information.
Independent Living Specialist 3 was interviewed on 8/4/2025,
via telephone. He has worked for the agency for 11 months. He
works the midnight shift. He denied knowledge of any
inappropriate sexual relationship between youths and male staff.
He denied ever being sexually involved with a female youth in the
program.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on 7/9/2025, with
MDHHS Worker. She reported she has lived in this home since
4/1/2025. Youth B reported she likes living in the program and
stated this was the most stable she has ever felt. She reported PM
comes by the program several times a week to check in and make
sure the youths are well and don’t need anything. She denied
seeing or hearing PM curse or call any of the youth’s names. She
stated PM can be blunt and honest, but she is not disrespectful.
Youth B reported she and Youth A were kind of close when Youth
A lived in the program, but Youth A has mostly been at her
boyfriend’s house. Youth B reported she could not recall the last
time she saw Youth A. Youth B denied knowing anything about
inappropriate sexual relationships between male staff and any
female youths in the program.
Youth C was interviewed on 7/9/2025, via face to face with
DHHS. She reported she lives in the house with Youth B and has
only been here for two weeks. She has her own room and likes
the house because it is peaceful and independent. She reported
there was nothing she disliked about being here. She stated if you
do not follow the rules, you can risk “getting kicked out.”
Youth C reported she gets enough to eat, and she feels safe. She
has never felt uncomfortable with any staff member. She reported
she met Youth A one time when she came to the house to grab
some of her belongings. She reported that PM was there at the
time and told Youth A she could not come and go as she pleased
but Youth A grabbed her clothing and left anyway. She reported
PM was not disrespectful towards Youth A or swore at Youth A.
Youth C denied knowing anything about inappropriate sexual
relationships between male staff and the female youths in the
program.
Youth D was not interviewed for this investigation. Information
provided from the agency was no longer active or in service.
5

MDHHS Worker attempted to contact Youth D for an interview but
to no avail. Youth D left the program March 2025.
DOCUMENT REVIEWED:
• Youth A’s case record – Youth A DOB 4/16/2017, was placed
with Community Care organization 2/5/2025 – 6/28/2025.
• Updated Service Plan dated 3/8/2025 – 6/5/2025. This plan
reported Youth A had numerous incident reports on going AWOL
from the program and breaking curfew. She tested positive for
smoking Marijuana.
• Social Work Contact dated 5/22/2025. This contact stated Youth
A mentioned she frequently spends time with her boyfriend, even
during school hours. PM advised Youth A it is unwise to skip
school or ignore curfews while participating in a program that does
not tolerate inappropriate behavior. The youth often fails to adhere
to curfews and does not comply with the established rules, which
leads to an Incident Report (IR). On 05/18/2025, Youth A was not
accounted for the entire day at CCO, which also resulted in a
missed curfew. On 5/20/2025, Youth A did not attend school due
to swollen eyes caused by a stye. On 5/21/2025, Youth A was
found smoking marijuana and refused to complete her chores. On
5/22/2025, Youth A missed curfew once more. On the same day,
Youth A left for school at 7:00 AM and did not return back to the
program, missing curfew again at 9:00 PM.
Analysis Violation was not established. Based on interviews from staff and
other youths in the program, PM was never observed using
inappropriate language towards Youth A or threatening to kick
Youth A out of the program. It appears PM is of responsible
character and suitable and able to meet the needs of the youths in
her care.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12506
Section Education/vocational training/employment
Description • (1) An agency shall ensure that it works with a youth
involved in independent living in the following areas as
outlined in the youth's service plan:
• (a) Employment.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation PM will not help Youth A find a way to get to Youth A's job at
Walmart, and Youth A is often accosted by men asking for sex
when she walks to work.
6

Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 7/9/2025 via telephone. Youth A
reported she is currently living with her boyfriend but did not want
to provide the address. When asked to discuss her current
employer and location of employer, Youth A reported she used to
work in the Garden City area but when she moved, she quit her
job. When asked how Community Care Staff were to assist her
with transportation while working if she refused to provide the
address of her location to pick her up from, she stated she didn’t
tell staff her address because she assumed they would decline
transportation. Youth A stated staff say no to her about everything.
The question was asked again of Youth A on how staff could
assist her if she refused to provide an address. Youth A reported
she did not give staff an address to her boyfriend’s house because
she did not want staff to know where she was living in fear they
would call the police to pick her up and she did not want to return
back to the agency. When asked her location of where the men
were who accosted her for sex when she was walking to work.
She reported they were in the Garden City area. She then quickly
changed the subject and reported no additional information about
her employment. Youth A stated staff say no to her about
everything.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed on 7/9/2025, face to
face with MDHHS Worker. She reported when Youth A was in
the Community Care Organization program she was not
employed. Her focus was on completing her credits to graduate
from high school and therapy twice a week. She said Youth A was
always AWOL from the program and did not let staff know her
location. She reported if Youth A worked it was when she had
AWOL’d from the program. PM reported to her knowledge, Youth
A did not have a job and if she did, staff would not transport her to
Garden City when she could work closer to her home in Detroit.
PM reported the only job she was aware of Youth A working was a
summer enrichment program where staff provided all
transportation there and back to the placement. PM reported
Youth A did not participate in her service plan or treatment goals
while due to being AWOL.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on 7/9/2025, with
MDHHS Worker. She reported Youth A never had a job working
at Walmart during her placement.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Social Work Contacts dated 4/4/025 – 6/28/2025. There was
never any mention of employment for Youth A.
7

• Updated Service Plan dated 3/8/2025 – 6/5/2025. There was
never any mention of employment.
Analysis Based on an interview from Program Manager, Youth B and
documentation, there was no employment record for Youth A. It
appears Youth A was not being trueful about being employed and
men accosting her while she had to walk to work while placed in
CCO.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12507
Section Medical, dental and mental health care
Description • (1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental,
and mental health care provided must be documented in
the youth's record.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A is three months pregnant, but PM refuses to offer her any
assistance or to take Youth A to doctor's appointments, even
though Youth A does not have a driver's license.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 7/9/2025, via telephone. She
reported she left Community Care Organization because PM was
telling her to get an abortion and would not help her obtain a
doctor’s appointment for her pregnancy. Youth A reported that PM
told her she was stupid, a “dumbass” for getting pregnant and
Youth A was going to end up alone and on the streets. Youth A
reported she is three months pregnant, and she now has to look
out for her unborn child. Youth A said it was summer and she
would not go back to her placement because she had nothing to
go back to. She reported she wanted the Community Care
Program to transport her to doctor’s appointments for pre
pregnancy treatment like getting vitamins and signing up for WIC.
She said she also wanted medical insurance for her unborn child.
However, she was not willing to take the chance of going back to
her placement and being talked about from the staff members.
Youth A reported she felt restricted, and she has rights, and she
knows her rights as a foster care youth.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed on 7/9/2025, face to
face with DHHS. She reported she learned Youth A was pregnant
on June 11, 2025, while staying at her boyfriend’s house. PM
8

reported she informed Youth A on June 11, 2025, that she was a
foster care youth and that she needed to return back to the
program by 5:00pm that day to participate in a life skills meeting
and remain in the program for the remaining of the day. PM
reported she informed Youth A she did not have permission to
stay out anymore. She reported she told Youth A if she did not
return, she would be placed on AWOL status and would have
another missed curfew. PM reported she informed Youth A she
needed to come back to the program so she could be enrolled in
programs that she needed for her health and the baby’s health.
PM reported she informed Youth A that Youth A has not allowed
the staff or PM to take her to any doctor’s appointments for proper
care. PM reported Youth A responded by stating the placement
was not her home, she would not be returning and all the staff in
the program make negative comments towards her since learning
she is pregnant. When questioned about which staff are treating
Youth A negatively or making inappropriate comments towards
her, PM reported Youth A identified one staff member, Case
Manager 4. PM reported she spoke with Case Manager 4 and
Case Manager 4 denied the allegations. PM reported she had a
staff meeting with all of the staff regarding speaking negatively
about or towards the youths in the program about their medical
issues or personal information.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on 7/9/2025, with DHHS.
Youth B reported she heard PM and Youth B discussing Youth A’s
pregnancy over the telephone. She reported she heard PM telling
Youth A her options and getting her needs met regarding housing,
a job and how difficult it is to have a baby with no plans and/or
permanent housing. Youth B said she overheard PM telling Youth
A she could help her find a mommy/baby program who will take
her and her child, but that Youth A needed to return back to the
program to receive those services.
Prior to Youth A’s last AWOL from the agency, she discussed her
pregnancy with Case Manager 4, on June 1, 2025. It is unknown
if Case Manager 4 shared this information with any other staff as
she resigned from the agency when this investigation was initiated
and there was no forwarding contact information for an interview.
Attempts were made to contact Case Manager 3 and Case
Manager 4. Case Manager 3 resigned from the program on
7/7/2025. She turned in her agency’s identification and provided
no warning she would be resigning. Case Manager 4 resigned on
7/1/2025. She did not call the agency or show up for work. Both
case managers did not leave updated contact information.
9

Telephone numbers left with the agency are no longer active.
DOCUMENT REVIEWED:
• Social Work Contact dated 6/12 2025, written by Case Manager
3. The note stated Case Manager 3 engaged in a phone
conversation with Youth A to inquire about her well-being. Youth A
informed Case Manager 3 about her discomfort at the program,
noting staff members have used inappropriate language towards
her. Case Manager 3 reported that Youth A recounted an incident
involving Case Manager 4 who referred to her with derogatory
terms after she disclosed her pregnancy. She said Youth A stated
Case Manager 4 made the suggestion she should consider
adoption and claimed she was making a grave mistake by being
pregnant with someone who does not care for her, warning that
she would regret her decision in ten years. Youth A expressed her
anger and mentioned she argued with Case Manager 4 and Case
Manager 4 called her stupid, and a “dumbass” and asked her
"What the F do you want me to do about it?" Case Manager 3
wrote she advised Youth A to contact her assigned case manager,
the supervisor and Case Manager 3. She reported Youth A
expressed reluctance, fearing that the supervisor may also insult
her.
Analysis There is insufficient evidence to support a rule violation. After
interviews were completed and documentation was reviewed, it
appears Youth A was offered assistance for medical appointments
but was AWOL and refused to come back to the program. Youth A
had discrepancies in her explanation for assistance as well.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
10

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
8/27/2025
___________________________________________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
9/02/2025

Area Manager
11
